Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Exploring the Evolution of an Extreme Makeover in Ferns
Award.AbstractNarration:
The "maidenhair ferns" (belonging to the genus Adiantum) are quintessential ferns -- beautifully dissected, terrestrial, and shade-loving. The "shoe-string ferns" (belonging to a group known as vittarioids) are extremely different: highly simplified, canopy-dwelling epiphytes, with duplicated genomes that exhibit accelerated rates of molecular evolution. Surprisingly, Adiantum and the vittarioids are closely related, comprising a single branch of the tree of life -- a lineage that evidently witnessed an extreme morphological, ecological, and genomic makeover. The proposed research aims to first establish a robust phylogeny for these ferns through analyses of DNA sequence data. Subsequent analyses can then reveal the evolutionary history of the "maidenhair" to "shoestring" fern transformation.


By better characterizing the evolutionary history of this extreme makeover in ferns, this study will better elucidate the evolutionary processes of morphological simplification, ecological transition, genome duplication, and molecular evolutionary rate acceleration. Because all of these processes are frequently encountered across the tree of life, but poorly understood, efforts here to uncover and characterize links among them are broadly relevant. This project encompasses a multidisciplinary training program to promote learning, teaching, and discovery, and is squarely aimed at undergraduate and graduate students interested in the areas of plant systematics, molecular evolution, and phylogenetics. The project will also pursue significant science education and outreach goals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Evolutionary studies often reveal surprisingly close relationships between organisms with radically different morphologies; for example, DNA data show that hippos are most closely related to whales! ….Wait!  What?!.....  One remarkable plant example is in the ferns, where the “maidenhair ferns” (Adiantum)––which are highly prized in horticulture because of their beautifully complex and dissected leaves––are most closely related to what are aptly called the “shoestring” (vittarioid) ferns, with leaves that are very simple and linear. These two fern lineages are a complete contrast in almost every biological aspect, and yet they are one another’s closest relatives. What evolutionary forces are at work to drive the remarkable morphological, ecological, and genomic disparities between these sister groups? The research supported by this award was designed to investigate the extreme biological makeover that occurred during the evolutionary history of the vittarioid ferns. The results of our phylogenetic studies provided us with several important new insights into the causes and effects of morphological simplification, ecological transformation, genome duplication, and molecular evolutionary rate acceleration—attributes that are frequently encountered (but poorly understood) across the tree of life. This in turn allowed us to reassess generic and subgeneric circumscriptions, and to contribute to the ongoing “nuclear revolution” in fern systematics by developing novel nuclear gene markers that can help us to understand such rampant processes as hybridization and polyploidy that confound the evolutionary patterns we see in ferns. The research supported by this award also contributed to the multidisciplinary training of undergraduate and graduate students interested in the areas of plant systematics, molecular evolution, and phylogenetics, and had science education and outreach components that targeted middle-school girls from local public schools.
